What do you want to redesign in Amazon website? It's working very well - one of our interviewees, was uncertain about the necessity of redesigning well known giant in the e-commerce world. After a few questions and taks, we were on the same side - it could work much better.

Table of contents

  • Preparation and Scope
  • Research
  • Information Synthesis
  • Concepts Generation
  • Interaction Vizualization
  • Ideation
  • Testing
  • Refining and Repeating

1. PREPARATION AND SCOPE

Type of project: Team project
Role: UX/UI Designer performing the following tasks:

✓interviews ✓persona ✓user journey map ✓user flow wireframing ✓prototyping ✓user testing
Tools: Sketch
Adobe Illustrator
Adobe Photoshop
InVision

2. RESEARCH

REDESIGN GOALS

Improving Account-Set-Up Flow
Adding-Products-to-Cart Flow
Showing Error in Payout Flow

SWOT ANALYSIS

ANALYSIS OF CURRENT AMAZON WEBSITE

1
Navigation bar is very cluttered. There are many categories which many customers do not use at all.
2
The drop down menu is one of the examples of poor information architecture. Only two sections with tens of links.
I don't like how long Amazon’s account current drop down menu is and would never go through all the content. I'd prefere more sections to organize information on current Amazon website.
1
Filters on the side on current amazon website are “a lot and overwhelming”. User needs to know what is hidden behind each of the filters name.
2
After choosing each filter the page is refined, but if the results don't match users expectations h/s is forced to go back and forth.
I don't like how much scrolling is involved on the side filters panel on current Amazon website. I am not able to refine search easily and do not know what category I am in on Amazon. The most frustrating is that I am unsure if all the filters I applied changed my results.

Early stage ideas

After inspecting the condition of current Amazon website and creating the SWOT Analysis, we run an initial brainstorming session. It helped us better understand what direction we want to go, form some early stage ideas and prepare questions for our surveys.
During brainstroming session we came up with some ideas which could help improve user experience:
✓ personalizing account
✓ adding more local store feeling to Amazon website
✓ supporting local/small businesses
✓ building network/community within Amazon to let the users see the reviews posted by people they know or influencers they follow insted of reading the random ones

Surveys

Initial interviews

During our initial interviews we were able to find following insights:

Interviews (6 people)

• Clicking Prime / 1 Day checkbox doesn’t properly filter products available for the next day!
• The need to remember about clicking 1 Day shipping option at checkout page is frustrating
• Time consuming typing name of the specific product in the search bar - lack of img search
• Many people were not aware of hidden features within users account
• Not intuitive filters / Too many options to select from
• Items on Wishlist don’t have the priority feature
• Help / Support - almost impossible to find contact information
• Orders / Subscriptions - they do not appear in chronological order
• Products sold by Small local / businesses are not visible
• Interviewees were concerned about quality of the products
• Some people don’t trust third party sellers

Whiteboarding and brainstorming

After thorough analysis of the current user flow and getting feedback from the interviewees, we started brainstorming and thinking about potential solutions:

3. INFORMATION SYNTHESIS

Main goals for redesign:

Proto Personas

User Persona

We created our persona basing on indept research and initial interviews with Amazon customers. Our persona reflects the behavior and motivations of the users we were interviewing.

Empathy Map

The next deliverable which gave us deep understanding of social behavior of our targeted audience was empathy map. We were observing or interviewees during the initial meeting, were listening to their responses, noticing their reactions. It helped us a lot with creating a map that reflets the needs and frustations of the representants of Amazon's clients.

4. CONCEPTS GENERATION

User Journey Map

Whiteboarding and creating user journey map helped us with identifying painful parts of the process and thinking about the opportunities. It was crucial for us to invision the whole process, to see where exactly the problem starts, in which stage of the process and what’s the best way to adress the user needs.

Findings and ideas how to solve the problem

Calendar feature
Make sure user is getting curated list of products which will be available for a desired day
Quick filters (icons)
Icons which represent different features of a specific product, work as quick filters, without using text descriptions
Decluttered interface
Clear of distractions interface that could pull the user away from shopping and checking out
Help / Support
Create a designated icon in the nav bar to let users find it easier
Wishlist
Introduce the feature of prioritizing the items on wishlist to let other ppl know what we want to receive in the first place
Subscriptions & Orders
Place the subscriptions and orders in chronological order - the most recent one at the top of the page
Highlighting features
Make icons (like IMG search) more highlighted, intuitive, easy to find; add label
Small and local businesses
Support small businesses and show their products as an alternative; add tab at product page

5. INTERACTION VISUALIZATION

After creating maps and graphs and thinking through our strategy, it was time to start puttting our ideas in the shapes of buttons, icons and other UI elemnts and create first wierframes.

Low fidelity paper wireframes

Wireframes - Version A

Wireframes - Version B

Wireframes testing findings

- Overall users liked the wireframes
- In the emails users preferred either icons only or bold text only, but not both. But they prefer just bold text.
- Users would keep the title of the email as not a link, would only have one link to the certificate because it might generate multiple copies.
- The wording on the emails felt “pandering and not endearing” they preferred it to say “Congratulations” or something more formal/serious.
- No need for icons on the email.
- They don’t mind having 2 links to download (one in the title, one in the body) but that it should be made clear it will download something, otherwise they wouldn’t like it.
- They like the Ace drawing.
- They would have the links next to the icons, not underneath header text.
- They like the icons.

Insights

I'd like more category suggestions for items that I am not familiar with. It would be great if less scrolling is involved (more condensed and concise information).
I wouldn’t press sign up button. I will probably first find product and then sign up. Users are more likely to sign up after they invested some time e.g. on research etc.

Style Guide

High-fidelity prototype

1
Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course
2
Email with less amout of steps and highlighted most important links
3
Pop-up with short instructions and reminder about the opportunity of having access to certs anytime

Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course

Email with less amout of steps and highlighted most important links
6
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates

11
Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course

13
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
14
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
15
Pop-up with short instructions and reminder about the opportunity of having access to certs anytime
16
Screen with miniature of certificate and two options ( download or print)
17
Last screen which appears when student is printing the certificate
High-fidelity prototype was created after couple of iterations. We utylized users feedback and changed the parts in the previous versions of our wireframes, which weren’t intuitive / effective enough. In the final version of the prototype we wanted to make sure that usres are not taking any unnecesarry steps towards checking out and placing the order.

7. TESTING

Usability testing

After utylizyng all of the findings from A/B testing and creating screens for high-fidelity prototypes, we tested them to make sure that user flows are seamless and users' needs are adressed adequately.
“All of the filters on the prototype seem to be applicable and make sense. It looks pretty streamline. I like it”

8. REFINING AND REPEATING

Conclusions

Amazon Redesign project was a huge learning for me. I learned a lot about conducting interviews and usability testings but also expanded my knowledge in the area of e-commerce industry. One of the most important things I discovered was to be customer-centric in my redesign approach, many times ask "Why" and don't necessarily trust my gut. I've also learned that testing everything helped us a lot with making sure that our redesign had an optomal impact not only on business but also on customer experience.
